summary:
I have been working as a medical data scientist for six years now in academic settings (McGill and Maastricht). Much of my research has focused on oncology (radiology and radiation oncology), but since the pandemic, the scope has increased to include COVID-19 research. I am currently funded by two COVID-related EU grants that I was instrumental in obtaining. I enjoy speaking to clinicians and understanding their needs, and am not the type of machine learning expert who seems to be speaking a foreign language. Identifying unmet clinical needs is how I choose to shape my research direction. I have a keen interest in medicine and am comfortable reading medical literature. While I love being a scientist, I am increasingly of the opinion that I want to see my work have a tangible positive effect on the lives of others. 

During my six-year career as a particle physicist (PhD from Cornell University), I analyzed data from the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) to search for evidence of physics unexplained by the established theory. Determining whether the observations were inconsistent with accepted theory required intimate knowledge of statistical tests and methods. My PhD thesis used artificial neural networks for classifying data into signal and background, at a time when machine learning was uncommon in particle physics. My training in particle physics, e.g., through my experience in rapidly updating data analysis code and assessing its performance, has made me a master of empirical evaluation. 

I have ample experience working in groups of varying sizes and hierarchical structures, and in producing software solutions to be utilized by a large user base. My research projects have included individuals of diverse races and ethnicities dispersed all over the world. I am receptive to feedback and new ideas irrespective of the speaker’s seniority. I have extensive experience focusing on personal efficiency, re-prioritizing tasks as needed, engaging in rigorous self-evaluation, and seeking feedback from peers. I strive to improve the functioning of my research group by identifying shortcomings, suggesting improvements, and helping set the course for future pursuits. In the last seven years, I have often played a supervisory role, and students have credited my firm but fair approach for making them a better researcher.

profile_positions.description:
• Leader of COVID-19 research into multi-factorial decision support systems for patient management at various stages of patient journey (diagnosis, theragnosis, follow-up); creator of a global app for longitudinal one-year follow-up of anyone diagnosed with COVID-19 to understand the effect of long COVID for non-hospitalized populations.
• Investigating correlations between diagnostic image features and clinical endpoints in oncology and other medical disciplines, a field known as radiomics. Since the field is relatively new and empirical,  playing fundamental role in advancement of the field by increasing statistical rigor. 
• Expert in handling medical datasets that are imbalanced with respect to the clinical outcome. Examining the limitations of the current state-of-the-art (SMOTE, ADASYN), while creating a novel methodology for machine learning on imbalanced data.
• Examining the efficacy of imputation methods in addressing the critical issue of missing data due to imperfect curation.
• Inventor of method (Dutch patent filed) for improving robustness of imaging biomarkers across scanner and imaging protocol variations using neural style transfer; leading the investigation on its use on real world data.
• Pioneering research in explainable AI to understand when simple machine learning tools are sufficient and when more advanced techniques like neural networks are warranted. Inventor of new algorithm based on nearest neighbors to solve the problem that a model with more than 5 features may not be interpretable; part of team studying and implementing techniques for interpretable and explainable AI for various projects in the department.

profile_positions.description:
• Expert in knowledge-based treatment planning, a field bringing machine learning to radiotherapy planning. Created models for treating glioblastoma and prostate cancer, with plan quality surpassing the standard of care. Results presented at multiple conferences and published.
• Pervasive problem in radiomics is small datasets, since medical institutions are often unwilling to share data. Invented a statistical methodology to make reliable predictions under the constraint of high dimensionality and low number of patients. Resulted in a provisional patent, multiple conference presentations and a publication.
• Significant hurdle for widespread adoption of radiomic models is inter-institutional variability, mainly in terms of imaging protocol and clinical practice. Developed an elegant statistical normalization method to reduce the impact. Resulted in multiple conference presentations and a publication. 
• Lead analyst of head-and-neck cancer outcome prediction study using dual-energy computed tomography (CT) imaging data. Scrutinizing whether using the whole tumor (3D) rather than single slice (2D) confers any prediction performance enhancement. Investigated iodine maps, an underutilized imaging technique, for outcome prediction.  
• Statistical and machine learning advisor for three projects on outcome modeling for cancer patients, one of which uses deep learning on patient CT imaging data.
• Founding member of Medomics consortium, a group of international scientists developing a state-of-the-art open-source software platform for end-to-end prediction modeling in cancer care. Primary role of statistical advisor.

profile_positions.description:
• Spearheaded the first-of-its-kind search for heavy neutral leptons, an elegant extension of the Standard Model that can resolve crucial unexplained cosmological observations. Developed suitable simulations and discovery strategies.
• Part of the group searching for highly ionizing particles, a novel signature of physics beyond the Standard Model (BSM), using 8 TeV LHC data; resulted in two publications. Led the related effort using 13 TeV LHC data.
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Fellow

profile_positions.description:
• Investigated Fast-Ion Instability (FII): leader of the team that made the first detailed bunch-by-bunch measurement of the effect, one of the dominant barriers to achieving ultra-low emittance. Adapted the FASTION simulation code, developed at CERN to study FII at the CLIC linac, to create detailed simulation of the effects anticipated at CESR-TA. Found good agreement with initial measurements. Results presented at conference, as well as published.
• Participated in the study of intra-beam scattering for electron and positron beams, another important effect likely to limit the performance of next generation colliders and storage rings: multiple publications and conference reports.
• Refurbished existing codes used to simulate, analyze and fit electron trajectory in an accelerator: a vital contribution to the collaboration.
